text.p: These are the leading stories in the Skopje press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Macedonian Prime Minister Branko Crvenkovski and leader of the largest opposition party Ljubco Georgievski negotiated on Wednesday possibilities of early elections and models of the election law.
- A group of depostiors of the bankrupt TAT financial institution mobbed owner of the bank Sonja Nikolovska almost to death while she was entering a building escorted by security guards.
- The Constitutional Court declared a new law on use of national minority languages as constitutional.
- Head of the IMF Michael Camdessus is on a three-day official visit to Macedonia to meet Macedonian high officials. Last month the IMF granted Macedonia $75 million in an ESAF arrangement.
- Four racketeers broke into private television station A1 on Tuesday night demanding a tape and the name of the author of political programme Suskavec.

- Owner of bankrupt TAT savings society Sonja Nikolovska confessed to making "fictitious arrangements and evading tax payments". She said she expected the state to forgive her as it did many other successful businessmen. -- Mircela Casule, Skopje newsroom +389 91 201 196
